text:
August 5, 1955.

Mr. Hugh Morrison,
1120 third Avenue N.W.,
Moose Jaw, Sask.

Dear Mr. Morrison:

Thank you for the copy of Pioneer Questionnaire No. 2 which you completed and returned to us recently. We are pleased to have this to add to the others filed for permanent preservation in the Archives. Under separate cover you will receive copies of the other Questionnaires which you indicated that you would be willing to answer, as well as the three new ones which have recently been prepared. It is in no respect only those who came to the province after 1905 that we are interested in hearing from, but on the contrary are very anxious to receive answers from those who settled the area in the days preceding Provincial establishment. It is the sum total of the experiences of individuals which give the picture of prairie settlement and development.

Yours sincerely,

Evelyn Eager
Assistant Archivist

EE/ed
August 5, 1955.

Mr. Hugh Horison,
1123 Third Avenue N.W.,
Moone Jav, Gaith.

Dear Mr. Horison:

Thank you for the copy of pioneer Questionnaire No. 2 which you exemplified and returned to us recently. We are pleased to have this to add to the others filled for permanent preservation in the Archives. Under separate cover you will receive copies of the other Questionnaires which you indicated that you would be willing to supply, as well as the three new ones which have recently been prepared. It is in no respect only those who came to the province contrary are very anxious to receive answers from those who settled the area in the days preceding Provincial establishment. It is the wish of all of the representatives of individuals which give the picture of pioneer settlement and development.

Yours sincerely,

Evelyn Barger
Assistant Archivist
HUGH RORISON

MOOSE JAW, SASK.

Blind Bay, B.C.,
Via Notch Hill,
July 26th, 1955.

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Dear Sirs:

I have filled out your questionnaire which I imagine applies more particularly to those who arrived in the province after its inauguration. I am sure the information I could give you regarding the history of my own community is completely detailed in your file. The story I would tell of transition from the time of the founding of the province will already have been told many times, by those more competent to tell it than I. Yet if there is any information you think I could supply I would endeavour to do so.

I do feel that I was very fortunate to have been raised on the "frontier", a wilderness but for a few hamlets along a thousand miles of a single line of railway, to see the prairie west transformed into a rich agricultural and industrial empire, to see great cities and innumerable smaller prosperous communities, where there had been nothing but blank prairie.

Yours very truly,

Hugh Rorison.
HUGH RORISON

MOOSE JAW, SASK.

Blind Bay, B.C.,
Via Noch Hill,
July 25th, 1955.

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Dear Sirs:

I have filled out your questionnaire, which I imagine applies more particularly to those who arrived in the province after its inauguration. I am sure the information I could give you regarding the history of my own community is completely detailed in your file. The story I would tell of transition from the time of the founding of the province will already have been told many times by those more competent to tell it than I. Yet if there is any information you think I could supply I would endeavour to do so.

I do feel that I was very fortunate to have been raised on the "Frontier", wilderness but for a few hamlets along a thousand miles of a single line of railway, to see the prairie west transformed into a rich agricultural and industrial empire, to see great cities and innumerable smaller prosperous communities where there had been nothing but blank prairie.

Yours very truly,

Hugh Rorison.
A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions have been added to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so it is very about leaving blank spaces. Use estimates of time if they are not sufficient space to answer the question. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events. If they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family own answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches and social life
- Pioneer residence experiences
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
Pioneer Experiences

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions may not be relevant to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer. You may not have enough space to answer all the questions. Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate pages or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

See list below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneer life in the bush
- Pioneer trades and business

Preparation of Questionnaire

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
St. Paul's College,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have said it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name .............................................. Hugh Ulmstead Rorison
2. Your address .............................................. 1120 Third Ave., N.W., Moose Jaw, Sask.
3. Date ......................................................... April 8th, 1955.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Hugh Ulmstead Rorison, Green Buyer.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   Was in Saskatchewan when charter given
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan,
   giving dates wherever possible.
   See above.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need
   to answer this question if you would not be able to answer it now.)
   I was in my early twenties when I came to Western Canada.
9. In three words describe your early life in the North-West Territories.
   I have spent my lifetime here and while I have a summer home at the
   Post Office of Blind Bay, B.C., my permanent mailing
   address is still Moose Jaw.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?
    Railroad or government information?).
    See Nos. 8 & 9.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so.

It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name .............................................. Hugh Ulmstead Rorison

2. Your address .............................................. 1120 Thira Ave., N.W., Moose Jaw, Sask.

3. Date ......................................................... 24th July, 1965.

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).

5. What was your father's name and occupation?

Hugh Ulmstead Rorison, Grain Buyer.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).

Was in Saskatchewan when charter given

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

See above.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (If you do not want to answer this question, if you would rather not or you may be too young to answer it, I would prefer that you not answer it.)

9. What were your reasons for coming here?

My lifetime there, and while I have a number of things to tell, my parents owned a farm in Manitoba, in 1909, I was only nine years old. I was one of seven children. I was in my teens when I came to Saskatchewan.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

See Nos. 8 & 9.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   See 8 & 9

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   See 8 & 9

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   By rail to St. Paul, Minnesota, then by the Great Northern Railway to Winnipeg. From Manitoba, of course, by C. P. R. to Moose Jaw.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   See 8 & 9

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   See 8 & 9

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   See 8 & 9

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   See 8 & 9

18. How did I earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came to age 21, I started working for Massey Harris Co., 4th Avenue, for 10 years as a clerk. In 1951 I bought my own business, B. J. Brown and Sons Hardware, in Moose Jaw. In latter years I continued my connection with Massey Harris Co. Ltd., I went into local merchandising in Moose Jaw and continued until my retirement in 1956.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

See 8 & 9

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

See 8 & 9

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Northern Railway to Winnipeg, then by the Great Northern Railway to Moose Jaw.

By Q.P.R. to Moose Jaw.

See 8 & 9

14. What highlights of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

See 8 & 9

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

See 8 & 9

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

See 8 & 9

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

See 8 & 9

18. How did I find work before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came to age 21, I started working for Harry Harris Co., with them for 10 years and then for Mr. B. Johnson and Imperial Oil Refinery for another 10 years, working my connection with Imperial Oil Refinery to 1932. After that, I worked at local machine shop lines in Moose Jaw and continued until my retirement in 1956.

See 8 & 9
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Not at all, see 8 & 9

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Before marriage my wife's name was Bertha H. Johnson, & school teacher in Moose Jaw. We were married June 9, 1915.

21. Did anyone else come to Johnathan Redge's place to settle?

see 8 & 9

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

I was the oldest member of our family. The other members of the family, four girls and three boys, were born in Western Canada, all but one in what is now Saskatchewan.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Any experiences I would wish to record applied mostly to the time previous to the formation of the province and not the time of the second great immigration 1897-1912.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

In the years 1901-1911 inclusive I travelled both loosely around Moose Jaw, and in all but the Northwest portion of the county. In the years 1911-1916 I was largely in touch with the northwestern part of the county and North Eastern Saskatchewan and later with the settlement of the area south and southwest of Moose Jaw to the present Weyburn-Lethbridge line.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Not at all, see 8 & 9

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Before marriage my wife's name was Bertha H. Johnson, & school teacher in Moose Jaw. We were married June 6, 1915.

21. Did anyone else come to Moose Jaw? If so, from what place to settle?
   See 8 & 9

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   I was the oldest member of our family. The other members of the family, four girls and three boys, were born in Western Canada, all but one in what is now Saskatchewan.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Any experiences I would wish to record, supplied mostly to the time of yours to the formation of the province and the time of the second great immigration 1889-1912.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?
   In the Years 1901-1911 inclusive, I travelled North locally around Moose Jaw, and in all but the Northwest portion of the Co., what is now Saskatchewan. Through my firm, Messrs. Smith & Co., I was regularly in touch with the new settlers in the central part of the area, south and southwest of Moose Jaw to the present Weyburn-Lethbridge line.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   I think the first car in our City of Moose Jaw was a "Zepa."
   Bought a second-hand "Revere" in the spring of 1932.

26. If so, what year?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   see 8 & 9

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing; better means of travel, etc.)
   see 8 & 9

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   see 8 & 9

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   see 8 & 9

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
    Most likely articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
    My parents purchased through Sears in the 1930s. The purchases were small, mostly dress goods.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
    Our home had a telephone about 1895. The owner of the small exchange was Mr. C.A. Gass, at that time the local...

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
    see 8 & 9
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If bought a car before 1930, what year did you get it?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

See 8 & 9

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

See 8 & 9

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

See 8 & 9

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Did you also buy what fraction of your total purchases made by other stores? What was the proportion?

My personal purchases through catalogues were small, while purchases were large.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

Our home had a telephone about 1945. The owner of the small exchange was Mr. C. A. Gass, at that time the local

33. When you came to Sonotsehan, the first thing was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

See 8 & 9
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

There was a tide of settlement to our area in the early 1800s. Railways reached Moose Jaw in 1882. These early homesteaders left their lands in 1866, a very dry year. All this, of course, lends a story of its own.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

As you are probably aware, about 100,000 people moved away from our province during the Thirties, contributing to the United States.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office or been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father was Mayor of the small town of Moose Jaw. I think the year of 1892. I have served as Alderman in our home city for several terms from 1924 to 1924 inclusive.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district, mention it here, citing dates whenever possible.

Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.

Cannot claim any such honours.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of the school district of Moose Jaw No. 1 in the Province of Saskatchewan and I expect of the N.W.T. Territories. There are many versions of the origin of the name "Moose Jaw." It spilled originally to the Creek, or river if you wish.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

There was a tide of settlement to our area in the early 1800s when the railway reached Moose Jaw. In 1892, our very large population of these early homesteaders left their lands in 1866, a dry year. All this, of course, goes toward promoting the growth of the province, a story of its own.

35. Did many people move away during the 1950s? Did many return?

As you are probably aware, about 100,000 people moved away from our province during the Thirties, called the "Great Migration," to the United States, Canada, and other parts of the world.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

By far the most important position I have ever held was that of mayor of Moose Jaw. I think the year of 1924 is significant, having served as alderman in our home city for several terms from 1922 to 1924 inclusive.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were members of any clubs or organizations (such as the Moose Jaw Automobile Club), organizing the first lodge, etc., cannot claim any such honors.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of the school district of Moose Jaw No. 1 in the Province of Saskatchewan, and the extent of the land in the name Moose Jaw. There are many versions of the origin of the name Moose Jaw. It is still used originally to the Creek, or river if you wish.
HUGH RORISON

MOOSE JAW, SASK.

Mr. David Watson, Post Office, I believe, Tuxford, Sask., has a fund of information re early farm associations, agricultural societies, grain grocers' associations, etc., apply more particularly to Moose Jaw and district.

Forbes McKenzie, Belheek, Sask., information re farm and farming activities.

Ben Thompson, 1068 Second Ave. N.W., Moose Jaw.

Mrs. J.J. Wallis, 258 Manitoba St. E., Moose Jaw, has a fund of information with regard to the early settlement of Moose Jaw, and, more particularly, of the part of a tribe of Sioux Indians who camped for most of each year just southwest of the town. There was quite a colored history attached to them. She had a collection of materials used by these Indians—Indian clubs, articles of clothing, artifacts, etc.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here!
HUGH RORISON

MOOSE JAW, SASK.

additional to No. 39.

Mr. David Watson, Post Office, I believe, Moose Jaw, Sask., has a fund of information re early farm associations, agricultural societies, grain growers' associations, etc., apply more particularly to Moose Jaw and district.

Forbes McKenzie, Belbeek, Sask., information re farm and farming activities.

Ben Thompson, 1068 Second Ave., N.W., Moose Jaw.

Mrs. J.J. Wells, 258 Manitoba St., E., Moose Jaw, has a fund of information with regard to the early settlement of Moose Jaw, and, more particularly, of the part of a tribe of Sioux Indians who camped for most of each year just southeast of the town. There was quite a colorful history attached to them.

She has a collection of materials used by these Indians—Indian clubs, articles of clothing, artifacts, etc.
39. Questions regarding historical source material:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organiza-
tions, old photographs, written recollections and remini-
ces? (Describe).
If it has not already been done; I would suggest you contact
the below-mentioned individuals:
Mrs. M.J. Bellamy, 457 Langdon Crescent, Moose Jaw. Times
Mrs. H. MacMillan, 260 Athabasca W., Moose Jaw, who has a
great fund of information about the early settlement
history of the Moose Jaw city end district. Has further
information as to old road locations, place names, etc.
Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative
Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?
........... (Indicate your preference, if any)
You would have to get in touch with individuals in regard to this.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they
live and occupations.
Have one daughter, married. Her name is Mrs. D. H. Crosbie,
1120 Third Ave. N.W., Moose Jaw. She has two children, boys,
see 6 and 46.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you
first came West?
Moose Jaw was made a division of the C.P.R. In 1882. It continued
to be an important railway town during the succeeding years. In
addition it had a rich agricultural area surrounding it, as a
consequence it has grown from a small pioneer settlement to a
city of some 28,000. It would be a long story to tell of the various
stages of the growth of this city and the various developments
of our local newspaper. The Moose Jaw Tribune has been the
situation here for a little different, or what I might be in regard
to the case of a small settlement in comparatively new area of
the province.

Please give the names and addresses of other planters who could answer this ques-
tionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person
give name and address here:

[Signature]

[Signature]
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).
If it has not already been done, I would suggest you contact the below-mentioned individuals:

Mrs. H.J. Ballew, 482 Langton Greenpoint, Moose Jaw Old timers
Mr. H. MacMillan, 260 Athabasca W., Moose Jaw, who has a great fund of information about the early settlement and settlement of the Moose Jaw city and district. Has further information as to old road locations, place names, etc.

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

........... (Indicate your preference if any)

You would have to get in touch with individuals in regard to this.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Have one daughter, married. Her name is Mrs. D.E. Grobelle,
1120 Third Ave., Moose Jaw. She has two children, boys,
ages 6 and 4.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

Moose Jaw was once a division of the C.B.R. In 1892, it continued to be an important railway town during the succeeding years. In consequence, it has grown from a small pioneer settlement to a city of some 28,000. It will be a long story to tell of the various stages of the growth of the city and to explain the full extent of this information in your file. The various social situations here are a little different to what it might be in regard to the case of a small settlement in a comparatively new area of the province.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Place att. on us

If anyone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
